titleInfo.title: Influence of TMT Cultural Distance in the Completion of Cross-Border Acquisitions

mods:mods.abstract: Research on cultural distance normally assumes corporate homogeneity within a country, which makes the untenable assumption that all firms within the country are culturally homogeneous. In addition, research on cultural distance has only found small or conflicting effects on several outcomes including acquisition performance. I contend that one reason for this is that corporate homogeneity has been left unaddressed. Research commentaries have consistently called into question the validity of such assumption; emphasizing the inappropriateness of the corporate homogeneity assumption or calling for a more microfoundational approach to cultural distance research. This study examines the influence of TMT cultural distance on the acquisition completion process. I argue that top management teams that are culturally closer to the target country are better able to alleviate information asymmetries; which in turn allows them to close acquisitions faster and with more certainty. I argue that being culturally close to the target country is a sign of knowledge about the target country which will help the TMT alleviate information asymmetries. In addition, I argue that this effect is weaker when the board is culturally close to the target country and when advisor country contemporaneous capital is high. In addition, I argue that the longer it takes to complete an acquisition, the worse the returns at completion are due to strained relationships from cultural distance. In this regard, I argue and find that TMT cultural distance has a negative indirect effect on returns at completion. I use a sample of 548 cross-border acquisitions by serial European acquirers. The sample contains information from 10,483 individual top management team or board members from 220 companies from 16 countries doing acquisitions in 41 target countries. I find support for the hypotheses relating to returns at completion; and some support for the main hypothesis on the relationship between TMT cultural distance and time to completion. Two things are of note relating the moderating hypotheses. First, the board of directors seems to have the opposite effect to expectations where a board of directors that is culturally close strengthens the relationship between TMT cultural distance. Second, advisors with country contemporaneous capital seem to help TMT's close a deal, but do not speed up completion. Altogether, this study suggests that researchers need to pay closer attention to the acquisition closing process and to the cultural composition of its leadership team.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Completion, Cultural Distance, International Strategy, Mergers and Acquisitions
R. Michael Holmes, Jr., Professor Directing Dissertation; Don M. Autore, University Representative; Bruce T. Lamont, Committee Member; David R. King, Committee Member.
